[[Neo-Nazism]]
[[White nationalism]]
[[White supremacism]]
[[Identitarian movement|Identitarianism]] | purpose = To spread support for white nationalism | affiliations = *Rise Above Movement {{Cite news|url=https://www.teenvogue.com/story/heres-why-hugging-white-supremacists-is-counterproductive-to-justice|title=White Supremacists Don't Deserve Hugs|last=Blades|first=Lincoln Anthony|work=Teen Vogue|access-date=2017-10-29|language=en}} | founder = Nathan Damigo | key_people = *Founder and leader Nathan Damigo (2016 – Aug. 2017) *Leader Elliot Kline (Aug.–Nov. 2017) [https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/09/26/identity-evropa-and-arktos-media-—-likely-bedfellows], [[Hatewatch]], [[Southern Poverty Law Center]], September 26, 2017 *Leader Patrick Casey (Nov. 2017 – present)[https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/12/05/patrick-casey-identity-evropa%E2%80%99s-new-leader-wants-ditch-alt-right-identitarianism%E2%80%94-another] | location = [[United States]] | website = {{url|https://www.identityevropa.com/}} | membership = roughly 800 as of July 2018{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/amp/ncna920826|title=White nationalist leader is plotting to 'take over the GOP'|date=2018-10-17|work=NBC News US|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-US}} }} '''Identity Evropa''' ({{IPAc-en|j|uː|ˈ|r|oʊ|p|ə}}) is an American [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.thetab.com/us/2017/02/15/nathan-damigo-identity-evropa-60697/|title=Meet the neo-Nazi coming to put up white pride posters on your campus|date=2017-02-15|work=The Tab US|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.snjtoday.com/story/36405127/neo-nazis-recruiting-on-local-college-campus|title=Stockton Investigating Unapproved White Supremacy Group Fliers on Campus|last=Baratti|first=Nina|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/11/27/identity-evropas-controversial-new-ringleader|title=Identity Evropa's Controversial New Ringleader|last=Kelley|first=Brendan|date=27 November 2017|website=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|quote=But not that long ago, in spring of this year, Mosley a/k/a Kline wasn't shy about the bigotry in his polemics whatsoever. In a report for Andrew Anglin's Daily Stormer about a pro-Trump demonstration in March, Mosley wrote, "In Philadelphia, the city of faggotry love, played out an alliance between the Nazi led marchers and local police departments against their oven-dodging enemies… Spoiler, the Nazis won bigly." He continues, "This is a sign that we have moved into a new era in the Nazification of America. Normie Trump supporters are becoming racially aware and Jew Wise."}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.kxly.com/news/white-supremacistdecal-found-at-gonzaga-university/706601484|title=White supremacist decals found at Gonzaga University|last=Gardner|first=Elena|date=2018-02-24|work=KXLY|access-date=2018-02-26|language=en-US}} and [[white supremacist]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-nathan-damigo-alt-right-20161115-story.html|title=In diverse California, a young white supremacist seeks to convert fellow college students|last=Branson-Potts|first=Hailey|date=2016-12-07|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-04-17|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Abigail|title=Charlottesville are Coming back with a Vengeance|url=http://www.newsweek.com/white-supremacists-charlottesville-campus-fliers-662659|accessdate=6 November 2017|publisher=Newsweek|date=September 11, 2017}}{{Cite news|authors=Dugan Arnett|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/2017/03/31/for-white-nationalists-college-campuses-are-new-recruiting-ground/MmxrcFXPY2ZHWycgvqCOAP/story.html|title=For white nationalists, college campuses are a new recruiting ground|work=Boston Globe|date=March 31, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://thefederalist.com/2018/02/07/right-cant-ignore-rise-white-supremacy-campus/|title=The Right Can't Ignore The Rise Of White Supremacy On Campus|date=2018-02-07|work=The Federalist|access-date=2018-02-26|language=en-US}} organization established in March 2016. The group is identified as a white supremacist organization by the [[Anti-Defamation League]]Susan Svrluga, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/03/06/unprecedented-effort-by-white-supremacists-to-recruit-and-target-college-students-group-claims/ 'Unprecedented effort' by 'white supremacists' to recruit and target college students, group claims], ''Washington Post'' (March 6, 2017).{{cite web |title=Identity Evropa |url=https://www.adl.org/resources/profiles/identity-evropa |website=Anti-Defamation League |accessdate=July 15, 2018 |location=New York, N.Y.}} and is [[List of organizations designated by the Southern Poverty Law Center as hate groups|designated]] by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] as a [[hate group]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/southern-poverty-law-center-says-american-hate-groups-are-on-the-rise/2017/02/15/7e9cab02-f2d9-11e6-a9b0-ecee7ce475fc_story.html|title=Southern Poverty Law Center says American hate groups are on the rise|author=Abigail Hauslohner|date=February 15, 2017|newspaper=Washington Post}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/15/politics/hate-groups-spiked-in-2016/index.html|title='A resurgence of white nationalism': Hate groups spiked in 2016|authors=Sara Ganim, Chris Welch & Nathaniel Meyersohnl|date=February 15, 2017|publisher=CNN}} Leaders and members of Identity Evropa, such as former leader Eli Mosley, have praised [[Nazi Germany]] and have openly pushed for what they say is the "Nazification of America". In an attempt to boost its numbers, Identity Evropa has allied itself with the broader white nationalist [[alt-right]] and [[identitarian movement]]s, and the group particularly targets college campuses, by distributing slogans on fliers, posters, and stickers.{{Cite news|author=Harry Shukman|url=http://thetab.com/us/2017/02/15/nathan-damigo-identity-evropa-60697|title=Meet the neo-Nazi coming to put up white pride posters on your campus|date=February 15, 2017|work=The Tab US|language=en-US}} It is one of several groups which have contributed to the rapid growth of white nationalism in the U.S. since 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/15/politics/hate-groups-spiked-in-2016/index.html|title='A resurgence of white nationalism': Hate groups spiked in 2016|authors=Sara Ganim, Chris Welch & Nathaniel Meyersohnl|date=February 15, 2017|publisher=CNN}}{{Cite web|url=http://eltecolote.org/content/en/features/alternate-reality-growing-acceptance-of-white-nationalism-in-trumps-america/|title=Alternate Reality: Growing acceptance of white nationalism in Trump's America|author=Alexis Terrazas & Atticus Morris|website=[[El Tecolote (newspaper)|El Tecolote]]|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-17}} In March 2018, it was reported that the group was seeing steep declines in membership. The collapse has been seen in other alt-right groups, and has been attributed to widespread public backlash against neo-Nazism and white supremacy since the [[Unite the Right rally|2017 Charlottesville rally]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/14/matthew-heimbach-neo-nazi-white-nationalism-arrest-domestic-violence|title=Prominent US neo-Nazi arrested on domestic violence charge|last=Walters|first=Joanna|date=March 14, 2018|website=[[The Guardian]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 15, 2018|quote=And the SPLC reported that its team monitoring far-right hate groups had seen recent signs on extremist chat boards that members of the racist US group Identity Evropa have been leaving in significant numbers.}} == History == The organization's founder, Nathan Damigo ({{IPAc-en|d|ə|ˈ|m|ɪ|ɡ|oʊ}}), is a self-described member of the [[identitarian movement]]. Damigo grew up in [[San Jose, California]], and was a member of the [[U.S. Marine Corps]] from 2004 to 2007. In November 2007, Damigo robbed a [[La Mesa, California]], taxicab driver at gunpoint, believing that the man was Iraqi.{{Cite web | last1=Sepulveda | first1=John | last2=Johnson | first2=Bert | date=August 14, 2017 | title=Berkeley was training ground for some in Charlottesville protests — Berkeleyside | url=http://www.berkeleyside.com/2017/08/14/berkeley-training-ground-charlottesville-protests/ | website=Berkeleyside.com | publisher=Berkeleyside | access-date=August 16, 2017 | quote=During a psychological evaluation conducted for the court as part of the criminal case, Damigo said he attacked the cab driver, Changiz Ezzatyar, because he mistook him for an Iraqi.}} Damigo was convicted of [[armed robbery]] and was incarcerated for a year in county jail and four years in state prison. He said of the event that "it's something that I'm certainly not proud of," attributing his behavior to "major issues" after returning from Iraq. In prison, Damigo began to read works by far-right figures, including former [[Grand Wizard|Imperial Wizard]] of the [[Ku Klux Klan]] [[David Duke]]. He was also influenced by [[J. Philippe Rushton]] and [[Nicholas Wade]]. After being released from prison in 2014,Alex MacLean, [http://www.uniondemocrat.com/home/4904465-151/white-nationalist-leader-not-from-sonora White nationalist leader not from Sonora], ''Union Democrat'' (December 14, 2016). Damigo led the National Youth Front, the youth wing of the [[American Freedom Party]]. The group was classified as a hate group by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC) and [[Anti-Defamation League]], with the SPLC reporting that it was founded by "racist Southern California skinheads that aims to deport immigrants and return the United States to white rule." The National Youth Front later disbanded. Damigo founded Identity Evropa in March 2016. His activities with "racist organizations" has been disavowed by his father.Gaffey, Conor (August 16, 2017) [http://www.newsweek.com/unite-right-charlottesville-nathan-damigo-trump-651266 "Unite the Right Organizer Disavowed by Family After Charlottesville Violence"] ''[[Newsweek]]'' In the aftermath of the [[Unite the Right rally]], the leadership position passed onto Elliot Kline, aka Eli Mosley. The group participated in the planning for the [[Richard B. Spencer#Speech at University of Florida|October 19, 2017 speech by Richard B. Spencer]], a white supremacist, at the [[University of Florida]], where Mosley also spoke. In addition to Spencer and Mosley, the speakers included [[Mike Enoch]], a white nationalist blogger.{{cite web|url=http://wfla.com/2017/10/19/richard-spencer-drowned-out-by-boos-at-uf-speech-call-for-firing-of-white-professors/|title=WATCH: Richard Spencer gets drowned out by boos at UF speech|date=19 October 2017|publisher=}}[https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/10/19/richard-spencer-shouted-down-university-florida-speech/781966001/ "'Go home, racist!' Richard Spencer shouted down at University of Florida speech"], ''[[USA Today]]'' The event drew about 2,500 protestors, vastly outnumbering Spencer's supporters.[http://www.newsweek.com/richard-spencer-shouted-down-florida-cuts-his-speech-short-689182 "Richard Spencer Shouted Down in Florida, Cuts his Speech Short"], ''[[Newsweek]]''[http://www.gainesville.com/news/20171020/behind-scenes-logistics-at-protest-let-officers-control-chaos "Behind-scenes logistics at protest let officers control chaos"], ''[[The Gainesville Sun]]'' ==Views== Identity Evropa is a neo-Nazi and white supremacist group;Cecilia Saixue Watt, [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/11/redneck-revolt-guns-anti-racism-fascism-far-left Redneck Revolt: the armed leftwing group that wants to stamp out fascism], ''The Guardian'' (July 11, 2017). the organization espouses [[white supremacist]] and [[white separatist]] views.Mike Anderson, [http://rapidcityjournal.com/news/pro-white-group-puts-up-posters-at-mines-and-bhsu/article_493b0c1b-baf7-5fc4-8c8b-a2512285c3a9.html Pro-white group puts up posters at Mines and BHSU], ''Rapid City Journal'' (March 5, 2017). The group endorses [[racial segregation]]. It "bills itself as a 'generation of awakened Europeans' who 'oppose those who would defame our history and rich cultural heritage'". Damigo describes it as "an identitarian organization" and says that the group's aim is to "act as a [[fifth column]], over time shifting the edifice of our political establishment" in favor of what he describes as "pro-white" interests. Identity Evropa's spokesman and director of administration, Reinhard Wolff, states that Identity Evropa is engaged in a "[[culture war]]" in an effort to create a "90 percent white" America. The white supremacist slogan "You will not replace us" originated from the group, according to the Anti-Defamation League, after Damigo and other members of Identity Evropa appeared on camera chanting the words during [[LaBeouf, Rönkkö & Turner]]'s ''[[HEWILLNOTDIVIDE.US]]'' project at New York's [[Museum of the Moving Image (New York City)|Museum of the Moving Image]] in February 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.adl.org/blog/white-supremacists-adopt-new-slogan-you-will-not-replace-us|title=White Supremacists Adopt New Slogan: "You Will Not Replace Us"|work=ADL Blog|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|date=June 9, 2017}} Identity Evropa excludes [[Jews]] from membership because Damigo regards Jews as non-white.Gabriel Thompson, [http://www.newsweek.com/golden-state-hate-extremism-history-california-561843 Golden State of Hate: Extremism's Long History in California], ''Newsweek'' (February 28, 2017). Only those "of European, non-Semitic heritage" may join the group. Damigo claims that "Jewish power, Jewish influence" has "been extraordinarily negative for people of European heritage". He has refused to say whether he [[Holocaust denial|acknowledges the Holocaust]]. The [[Anti-Defamation League]] has labeled Identity Evropa a white supremacist group, and the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC), which tracks extremist groups in the United States, has designated it as a hate group.{{Cite news|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/extremist-files/ideology/white-nationalist|title=White Nationalist|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|access-date=April 17, 2017|language=en}} Their campus-centric advertising posters depict photos of classical Greek sculptures of men overlaid with various short slogans which urge whites to embrace cultural elitism. Mark Potok, a senior fellow at the SPLC, states, "Identity Evropa is merely the latest iteration of the white-supremacist movement. Although you might think, based on their propaganda, that they're all about Plato and Aristotle and Socrates, in fact they're merely a gussied-up version of the Klan." [[Anna North]], writing in the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'', states that the group promotes racism under the guise of white racial pride and cultural identity for those who are of European ancestry.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/16/opinion/lets-become-great-again-the-flyers-said.html|title='Let's Become Great Again,' the Flyers Said|last=North|first=Anna|date=February 16, 2017|work=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331}} ==Activities== In December 2016, the group had roughly 200 members. In a February 2017 interview, Damigo claimed a membership of 300. The group has distributed fliers on dozens of colleges campuses, including the [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]], [[UCLA]], [[University of California, San Diego]], [[Penn State University|Penn State]], [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]], and the [[University of Washington]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.ksfy.com/content/news/White-supremacist-posters-appear-at-2-South-Dakota-colleges-415430093.html|title=White supremacist posters appear at 2 South Dakota colleges|agency=Associated Press|date=March 5, 2017|language=en}} According to an ADL count, Identity Evropa was by far the most active white supremacist group on college campuses in 2017, responsible for 158 of the 346 incidents nationwide of the posting of white supremacist propaganda fliers.Rachel Frazin, [https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2018-02-21/identity-evropa-elicits-concern-on-campus Identity Evropa Elicits Concern on Campus], ''U.S. News & World Report'' (February 21, 2018). These fliers typically show photos of [[Classical sculpture|classical]] and [[Neoclassicism#Sculpture|neoclassical sculpture]]. According to art critic [[Ben Davis (art critic)|Ben Davis]], the random use of dissimilar photos demonstrates a poor understanding of European culture and art history.{{cite news |last1=Davis |first1=Ben |authorlink1=Ben Davis (art critic) |title=White Nationalism's New Love of Art History, Decoded|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/identity-evropa-posters-art-symbolism-881747 |accessdate=25 June 2018 |work=artnet News |date=7 March 2017|quote=But when you look into the sources, the images themselves suggest an awareness of this culture that doesn't go much deeper than visual cliché. Instead, what you find is a hodgepodge; an identity pieced together in internet forums, from tourist pictures and Google image searches; militant ignorance masquerading as tradition.}} At Ohio State, the group has considered seeking recognized student organization status.{{Cite web|url=https://onwardstate.com/2017/04/13/meet-the-white-identitarian-group-here-at-penn-state-thats-growing-in-numbers/|title=White 'Identitarian' Group Identity Evropa Considers Seeking Student Org Recognition|date=April 13, 2017|website=Onward State}} The group's "#ProjectSiege" aims to "siege" college campuses with literature in order to combat what Damigo describes as a "false anti-white narrative" by teachers, whom Damigo calls "charlatans."{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/10/10/veteran-posts-signs-at-colleges-telling-whites-to-be-great-again.html|title=Veteran Posts Signs at Colleges Telling Whites to Be 'Great Again'|last=Nestel|first=M. L.|date=October 10, 2016|website=The Daily Beast}} In late 2016, Damigo and Identity Evropa members traveled to Washington, D.C., for a post-election conference hosted by the white supremacist [[National Policy Institute]], at which keynote speaker [[Richard B. Spencer]] and several other attendees rendered a [[Nazi salute]]. During the [[2017 Berkeley protests]], Damigo punched a young woman, captured on video that subsequently went [[Viral video|viral]].Christin Ayers, [http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2017/04/16/viral-video-shows-white-supremacist-sucker-punch-berkeley-anti-trump-protester/ Viral Video Shows Student White Supremacist Sucker-Punch Berkeley Anti-Trump Protester], CBS San Francisco ([[KPIX-TV]]/[[KCBS (AM)|KCBS]]) (April 16, 2017). Footage showed Damigo punching the woman in the face, then running away into the crowd.{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-nathan-damigo-stanislaus-state-20170417-story.html|title=Cal State Stanislaus to investigate white supremacist student who punched woman in Berkeley melee|last=Branson-Potts|first=Hailey|date=2017-04-17|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-04-17|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} The attack prompted calls for Damigo's arrest or expulsion from [[Cal State Stanislaus]], where he is a student; the university subsequently said that it was investigating Damigo. Damigo has been identified as a leader in the August 2017 [[Unite the Right rally]]. A news source that has interviewed him states that "Damigo has made these rallies a key driver for recruiting new members of the group".{{cite web|last1=Johnson|first1=Bert|title=Californian Who Helped Lead Charlottesville Protests Used Berkeley as a Test Run|url=https://ww2.kqed.org/news/2017/08/14/californian-who-helped-organize-charlottesville-protests-used-berkeley-as-a-test-run/|website=KQED News|accessdate=August 17, 2017}} Additionally, Peter Cvjetanovic, one of the members of Identity Evropa, was dubbed as the "angry torch guy" in the [[Unite the Right rally]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/charlotteville-photo-student-peter-cvjetanovic-not-angry-racist-white-nationalists-uva-university-of-a7891791.html|website=The Independent|accessdate=August 14, 2018|date=August 14, 2017|last1=Khan|first1=Shehab|title=Charlottesville photo: Man shouting angrily at white supremacist rally insists he is not an 'angry racist'}} On July 28, 2018, around 45 members of Identity Evropa, some dressed as construction workers, demonstrated outside the Mexican consulate in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], holding large letters that spelled out "Build the Wall". The government of Mexico said it had written a diplomatic note to the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] protesting the incident.{{cite news|last1=Reuters|title=Mexico Condemns Anti-Immigrant Chants Outside New York Consulate|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2018/07/31/world/americas/31reuters-mexico-usa-racism.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=July 30, 2018}} Later that day, a group of several dozen Identity Evropa members hung a banner in [[Fort Tryon Park]] in [[Upper Manhattan]]. The banner, which said "Stop the invasion, end immigration", overlooked the [[Henry Hudson Parkway]]. The response of the [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]] and [[Inwood, Manhattan|Inwood]] communities was to hold a "vigil against hate" at the same site on July 31.Del Signore, John {July 31, 2018) [http://gothamist.com/2018/07/31/fort_tryon_park_hate_group.php "White Supremacists Unfurl Anti-Immigration Banner In Fort Tryon Park"] ''[[Gothamist]]''{{cite news|last1=Ramey|first1=Corinne|title=White Nationalists Rally in Liberal New York|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/white-nationalists-rally-in-liberal-new-york-1533073903|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=July 31, 2018|date=July 31, 2018}} ==See also== {{Portal|Fascism|Discrimination}} * [[Ghost skin]] * [[New Nationalism (21st century)]] * [[White genocide conspiracy theory]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/05/insider/confronting-a-white-nationalist-eli-mosley.html How Our Reporter Uncovered a Lie That Propelled an Alt-Right Extremist’s Rise] {{Alt-right footer}} {{White nationalism}} {{Neo-Nazism}} [[Category:Alt-right]] [[Category:2016 establishments in California]] [[Category:White nationalism in the United States]] [[Category:White supremacist groups in the United States]] [[Category:Neo-Nazism]] [[Category:Neo-Nazi organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Identitarian movement]] [[Category:Identity politics in the United States]] [[Category:Third Position]]

{{redirect|Krsnik|the Slavic deity|Krsnik (deity)}}
A '''Krsnik''' or '''Kresnik''' is a type of vampire hunter, a shaman whose spirit wanders from the body in the form of an animal. The ''krsnik'' turns into an animal at night to fight off the ''kudlak'', his evil [[vampire]] antithesis, with the ''krsnik'' appearing as a white animal and the ''kudlak'' as a black one.<ref name=Perkowski>{{cite book|last=Perkowski|first=Jan L.|title=The Darkling: A Treatise on Slavic Vampirism|year=1989|publisher=Slavica Publishers|location=Columbus, Ohio|isbn=978-0-89357-200-6|pages=31–32}}</ref> The ''krsnik'' 's soul leaves the body, either voluntarily or due to a higher power, to fight evil agents and ensure good harvest, health, and happiness.<ref name="Shamanism on Slovenian Territory">{{cite journal|last=Šmitek|first=Zmago|title=Shamanism on Slovenian Territory? Dilemmas Concerning the Phenomena of Shamanism, Spirit Possession and Ecstasy|journal=Studia ethnologica Croatica|date=December 2005|volume=17|issue=1|pages=171–198|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?lang=en&show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=8019}}</ref>
The legend evolved from a pre-Christian myth present in [[Slovenia]] and [[Croatia]] (mainly [[Istria]] and the islands), where the celestial pagan god [[Perun]] is locked in eternal combat with the evil snake of the underworld, [[Veles (god)|Veles]].<ref name=Vinscak>{{cite journal|last=Vinšćak|first=Tomo|title=On "Štrige", "Štriguni" and "Krsnici" on Istrian Peninsula|journal=Studia ethnologica Croatica|date=December 2005|volume=17|issue=1|pages=221–235|url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=8023&lang=en}}</ref> The ''krsnik'' is taught magic by ''[[Vila (fairy)|Vile]]'' (fairies),<ref name="Slovene Folklore">{{cite journal|last=Copeland|first=F.S.|title=Slovene Folklore|journal=Folklore|date=December 31, 1931|volume=42|issue=4|pages=405–446|jstor=1256300|doi=10.1080/0015587x.1931.9718415}}</ref> and in traditional medicine has the ability to heal people and cattle.<ref name=Vinscak/> However, due to the undocumented nature of oral tradition, it's difficult to determine with certainty how much of ''kresnik'' folklore originated from Slavic mythology (''[[Kresnik (deity)]]''), and how much arose from a separate shamanistic tradition.<ref name="Mythological Reconstruction">{{cite journal|last=Šmitek|first=Zmago|title=Kresnik: An Attempt at Mythological Reconstruction|journal=Studia Mythologica Slavica|year=1998|volume=1|pages=93–118|url=http://sms.zrc-sazu.si/pdf/01/SMS_01_Smitek.pdf}}</ref> After [[Christianization]], the ''kresnik'' instead was claimed to have learned magic at the School of Black Magic in [[Babylon]], but retained benevolent traits as a generous and powerful friend of the poor.<ref name="Slovene Myths">{{cite journal|last=Copeland|first=Fanny S.|title=Slovene Myths|journal=The Slavonic and East European Review|date=April 1933|volume=11|issue=33|pages=631–651|jstor=4202822}}</ref>
The origin of the name may be from the word ''krst'', which means "cross",<ref name=Perkowski /> and which in Serbia is the word for a stone sign denoting village boundaries.<ref name="Shamanism on Slovenian Territory" /> It may also be derived from the same root as the Slav word for "resurrection,"<ref name="Slovene Myths"/> so that the word itself means something approximating "resurrector." <ref name="Slovene Folklore"/>
Similar beliefs circulated among the Italian [[Benandanti]] cult. Also see [[zduhać]].
== In fiction == * In the anime series ''[[Trinity Blood]]'', a "Crusnik" is a [[Vampire fiction|vampire]] that feeds on the blood of other vampires. ''Lilith Sahl, Cain, Seth, and Abel Nightroad'' are [[Crusnik (Trinity Blood)|Crusnik]] who are much more powerful than regular vampires. In the anime series, they all take different forms: Cain appears as an [[angel]] with white wings, even though he is the [[antagonist]], whereas Abel appears slightly [[demon]]ic with black wings and red eyes, while being the [[protagonist]]. Kudlak also appears in the series as a bacillus that is responsible of the creation of "normal" vampires. * ''Kresnik'' and ''Kudlak'' are recurring characters in the [[Shin Megami Tensei]] series of video games. * ''Kresnik'' is the name of a mythological hero in ''[[Tales of Xillia]]''. A superweapon bearing the name "Lance of Kresnik" is a plot device. The sequel features a descendant named Ludger Will Kresnik. A machine named ''Kudlak'' is also present, though unimportant to the story.
==See also== * [[Kresnik (deity)]] * [[Vampire hunter]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox professional wrestler |name = Leroy McGuirk |names = Leroy McGuirk |image = Leroy McGuirk.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = |height = |weight = |children = [[Mike McGuirk]] |birth_name = Leroy Michael McGuirk |real_height = |real_weight = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1910|12|13}} |birth_place = [[Garvin, Oklahoma]], [[United States]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1988|9|9|1910|12|13}} |death_place = [[Claremore, Oklahoma]] |resides = |billed = |trainer = |debut = 1933 |retired = 1950 |website = }} '''Leroy Michael McGuirk''' (December 13, 1910 - September 9, 1988) was an [[United States|American]] [[wrestler]] and [[professional wrestling]] [[Professional wrestling promotion|promoter]]. He was involved in professional wrestling for more than fifty years. As one of the longest surviving members of the [[National Wrestling Alliance]] (NWA), he was affiliated with the promotion from 1949 to 1982.
==Early life== He was born in [[Garvin, Oklahoma]]. He suffered the loss of his father before he was twelve and had to endure the loss of sight in one of his eyes due to a swimming mishap. McGuirk overcame many adversities to persevere in wrestling. He started wrestling at [[Central High School (Tulsa, Oklahoma)|Tulsa Central High School]] and competed at [[Oklahoma State University–Stillwater|Oklahoma A&M]] from 1928 to 1932 under Edward Gallagher.<ref name=p222>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 222, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref>
Despite losing in the quarterfinals of the 1930 NCAA Tournament, McGuirk claimed the 155-pound title at the 1931 NCAA Tournament on March 28 in Providence.<ref name=p222/> A year later, McGuirk competed in the 1932 NCAA Tournament at 174 pounds.
==Professional career== After graduation from college, McGuirk went to work for [[Sam Avey]]. On March 5, 1934, he beat Hugh Nichols in [[Tulsa]] for the [[World Light Heavyweight Championship (National Wrestling Association)|NWA World Light Heavyweight Championship]].<ref name=p222/> He was also endorsed by the [[National Wrestling Association]].
===Championship runs=== McGuirk enjoyed several runs as champion. On May 16, 1938, McGuirk beat [[Danny McShain]] to capture his second world light heavyweight title.<ref name=p222/> The [[National Wrestling Association]] had a 190-pound title (later raised to 200) that was known as the [[World Junior Heavyweight Championship (National Wrestling Association)|World Junior Heavyweight Championship]]. McGuirk won this title on June 19, 1939 from John Swenski.<ref name=p222/>
Between Tulsa and Hollywood, McGuirk dominated the Junior Heavyweight division, but at least three other Junior Heavyweight Champions were recognized at the time. On December 28, 1949, McGuirk unified the National Wrestling Association World Junior Heavyweight Championship with the [[NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship|National Wrestling Alliance’s version]] by defeating Billy Goelz in [[Des Moines]].<ref name=p222/>
Leroy McGuirk is credited as the longest male single's champion of all time. He captured the National Wrestling Association World Junior Heavyweight Title on 6-19-1939 and had to vacate the title on 2-7-1950, for a title run of 3886 days (10yr-7m-19d).
===Automobile accident=== On February 7, 1950, McGuirk’s career came to an end. In [[Little Rock, Arkansas]], McGuirk was being driven to a restaurant by his wrestling pupil, Robert "Bob" Clay. In an attempt to prevent a collision, Clay locked the car’s brakes, and McGuirk was thrown against the front windshield.<ref name=p223>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 223, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref> McGuirk’s tinted glasses were shattered and the side of the glasses covering his good eye were fractured, blinding McGuirk permanently. It was another Oklahoman, [[Danny Hodge]], who rose to prominence in the Junior Heavyweight field. By 1960, Hodge became the principal headliner for McGuirk.
===Booking and promoting=== After the accident, Avey kept McGuirk as a partner. McGuirk became second vice-president of the NWA from September 1950 to August 1956, and from August 1959 to August 1960.<ref name=p223/> Between 1957 and 1958, McGuirk was made an honorary vice-president. One of McGuirk’s first challenges as vice-president was to reconcile the promotional war that occurred between women’s wrestling promoters [[Billy Wolfe]] and his ex-wife [[Mildred Burke]]. McGuirk aligned himself with Burke and hoped to resolve the dispute at the September 1953 NWA meeting in Chicago.<ref>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 291, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref>
By 1953, McGuirk was the primary [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Book|booker]] for the junior heavyweight champion, while coordinating talent from southwestern Missouri to Little Rock, across Oklahoma, and into parts of Texas.<ref>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 280, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref> Despite being the booker, McGuirk also took on the opportunity to train promising wrestlers. One of his most promising was eventual NWA World Heavyweight Champion [[Dick Hutton]]. In the May 10, 1953 edition of the ''Tulsa Daily World'', McGuirk said ''"He has a fine chance to get into the big money brackets. He has a lot to learn, but has the natural qualifications, and I won’t be surprised at anything he may accomplish."''<ref>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 205, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref> Hutton did not disappoint, as he beat [[Lou Thesz]] on November 14, 1957 at [[Maple Leaf Gardens]] in Toronto.<ref>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 206, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref>
Avey and McGuirk’s actual territory covered most of Oklahoma and Arkansas. Said territory also included [[Joplin, Missouri|Joplin]] and [[Springfield, Missouri]], [[Shreveport, Louisiana]], plus [[Wichita Falls, Texas|Wichita Falls]], and [[Tyler, Texas]]. On January 4, 1958, McGuirk took over the entire business after Avey retired.<ref name="p233"/> Avey left wrestling to concentrate on his role as senior vice president of the Farmers and Merchants State Bank.<ref>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 281, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref> One of the biggest issues McGuirk faced was the tension that occurred due to sporadic visits by world champion [[Buddy Rogers (wrestler)|Buddy Rogers]] in the early 1960s. Many felt that the bigger promoters were locked in for visits by Rogers while territories such as McGuirk’s, [[Jim Crockett]] in Charlotte, [[Karl Sarpolis]] in Amarillo, and [[Cowboy Luttrall]] in Tampa, to name a few, were perceived as the non-essential territories.<ref>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 184, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref>
====Bill Watts==== {{Main|Bill Watts}} McGuirk had many people who worked for him as matchmaker: Leo Voss, Sam Menacker, Rip Tyler, Wayne Martin, and [[George Scott (wrestler)|George Scott]]. Of all those people, Cowboy Bill Watts played a big part in McGuirk’s promotion, both positively and negatively. His first real connection to McGuirk was in 1968, when McGuirk submitted the only vote in favor of passing the NWA Championship to him.<ref name=p351>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 351, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref> McGuirk and Watts worked together to promote Oklahoma, Arkansas, Mississippi, and Louisiana in the late 1970s. On July 22, 1978, their joint promotion of a wrestling show at the [[Louisiana Superdome]] drew an estimated 31,000 fans and a gate of $140,000.<ref name=p351/> A dispute between the two in August 1979 strained their friendship. While Watts incorporated Mid-South Sports Inc. and had agreements [[Jim Barnett (wrestling)|Jim Barnett]], [[Eddie Graham]], [[Fritz Von Erich]], and [[Vincent J. McMahon]] that made the promotion thrive.<ref name=p351/> McGuirk became desperate and hoped that George Scott would help keep the territory afloat.
On February 23, 1981, Watts filed documents to bring Mid-South to Tulsa. Matters worsened as seven wrestlers went on strike on August 21. Their grievance was that McGuirk had not paid them for the previous weeks work.<ref name=p351/> Despite turning to Amarillo for wrestling talent, McGuirk saw the writing on the wall.
In 1982, McGuirk ceased operations and left the city open for Bill Watts and [[Mid-South Wrestling]] to take over.<ref name=p233>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 233, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref> One of McGuirk’s daughters, Michael, better known in wrestling as [[Mike McGuirk]], married [[B. Brian Blair]], a wrestler for Mid-South. Both eventually worked for the World Wrestling Federation: Blair as one half of the tag team [[The Killer Bees (professional wrestling)|The Killer Bees]], and Mike McGuirk as an in-ring announcer.
==Honors== McGuirk was inducted into the Oklahoma Athletic Hall of Fame in 1977.<ref name=p233/> He is also a member of the [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame]]. Of his charitable work, McGuirk is best known for working with [[Ed Lewis (wrestler)|Ed Lewis]]. They were responsible for instituting the NWA "Leader Dogs for the Blind" annual charity function.
He died on September 9, 1988 in [[Claremore, Oklahoma|Claremore]].
==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[Central States Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]) *'''[[George Tragos/Lou Thesz Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' **Class of 2004 *'''[[National Wrestling Association]]''' **[[World Junior Heavyweight Championship (National Wrestling Association)|NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship]] ([[World Junior Heavyweight Championship (National Wrestling Association)#Title history|1 time]]) **[[World Light Heavyweight Championship (National Wrestling Association)|NWA World Light Heavyweight Championship]] ([[World Light Heavyweight Championship (National Wrestling Association)#Title history|3 times]]) *'''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum|Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' **[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum#Inductees|Class of 2014]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Other_News_4/article_74781.shtml|title=News: Pro Wrestling Hall of Fame announces 2014 HOF class|date=2013-11-26|last=Caldwell|first=James|accessdate=2013-11-26|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref> *'''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards]]''' **[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame]] ([[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame#1996 inductees|Class of 1996]])

[[File:Façade de la B.I.M.C. (jusqu'en 2002).jpg|thumb|Facade of the B.I.M.C. (until 2002)]]
The '''Library Božidar Kantušer''', formerly known as International Library of Contemporary Music (in French: Bibliothèque Internationale de Musique Contemporaine, B.I.M.C.), is a [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit association]] chartered under the French 1901 Law on associations. It was created in 1968 to promote contemporary music by facilitating access to published and unpublished [[Sheet music|scores]] from around the world. For this purpose, the [[Music library|library]] centralizes (without aesthetic bias) and lists the scores, and then facilitates their discovery by [[Computer science|computerized]] means. At its inception the association was subsidized by the [[Fontainebleau|City of Fontainebleau]] and the [[Minister of Culture (France)|French Ministry of Culture]], further by the [[Paris|City of Paris]] and the ''Ministry of Culture''. Since 2006, the collection of ''scores'' and [[Sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] (more than 24,500 documents in 2012) is available in ''Paris'' at the Médiathèque Hector Berlioz and through its [[Online public access catalog|OPAC]].
== Goals == « The dispersion of scores of music of our time among [[Publishing|publishers]] throughout the world (and especially the fact that most of them remain in the form of [[Music manuscript|manuscripts]]) represents an almost insurmountable obstacle for anyone wishing to obtain an exact idea of contemporary music production. Only an association of the persons actually concerned, that is to say the [[composer]]s and ''music publishers'' themselves, supported by musicians and other music professionals could overcome this problem. » (Excerpt from a B.I.M.C. bulletin)
== Means ==
=== Centralization and computerization === To allow the consultation of the deposited works and to establish the database necessary for the distribution of information, the library proposes to centralize the published and unpublished works of contemporary music (from the twentieth century on) and their recordings. The deposit of scores and recordings is open to all composers, without aesthetic bias, to the exclusion of pieces solely dedicated to education. The library regularly stimulates composers and publishers in depositing their works, emphasizing the promotional importance of such a deposit. In an effort of multi-centralization, of creating various consultation sites, for a few years composers and publishers were asked to submit several copies of each score. Cooperation talks were underway with the [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]], and the effort was carried out in the form of a second center in [[Slovenia]] from 1975 to 1985 (the idea was revived in 1999, then abandoned). [[File:Exemple annoté d'une fiche de la B.I.M.C..jpg|thumb|Annotated example of a B.I.M.C. index card]] For each submitted work, an [[index card]] was established and printed numerously. To allow multiple filing of each index card, the database for each deposited score contained the following information: name and surname of the composer, year and country of birth as well as nationality, title of the work, duration, year of composition, [[Instrumentation (music)|instrumentation]] ([[nomenclature]]), possibly the publisher and the year of publication. Subsequently the data appeared in printed directories, and was eventually entered on the site of the Médiathèque Hector Berlioz. In addition, a biographical file is opened for each composer and made accessible. All information often not being specified in the scores, one of the major tasks of the association is to obtain all the data needed to establish an entry.
=== Diffusion of information === The distribution of data permitting an objective and comprehensive information on contemporary works of music is done nowadays online through the ''OPAC'' of the Hector Berlioz Mediathèque. Previously, printed directories, presented in two volumes - one classified by instrumentation, the other in alphabetical order of composers, were regularly updated, reprinted and sent to subscribers around the world. They held and still hold an important place in music libraries (academic or public) in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Europe]], [[Australia]] and [[Japan]]. Initially (starting 1968), the diffusion of information was done by sending [[Library catalog|card catalog]]s to subscribers, allowing multiple approaches and regular updates. The seven card catalogs offered to subscription were ordered alphabetically by composer name, by instrumentation, by nationality and alphabetically, by nationality and instrumentation, by the duration of the work, by year of composition, by publisher (unpublished works by instrumentation). One same ''index card'', printed numerously and corresponding to one score, appeared in seven different ''card catalogs'', allowing to discover each work by seven different accesses. Interested parties subscribed to one or more card catalog of their choice, updating their catalogs as and when new cards were shipped. Index cards were shipped to subscribers as new works were deposited in the library.
== History == At its inception in 1968, composers such as [[Henri Dutilleux]], [[André Jolivet]], [[Darius Milhaud]] and [[Henri Sauguet]] gave their written support to the library. It also received a favorable press release, particularly in [[Les Lettres Françaises]], or with [[Combat (newspaper)|Combat]] welcoming the fortunate initiative. Many musical institutions from around the world soon began to follow with interest the development of the association. The first headquarters of the B.I.M.C. was in ''Fontainebleau''. It was situated on the first floor of the Villa Lavaurs, the basement housing technical services such as a recording studio and a press. In the early 1970s the headquarters was transferred to ''Paris''. Until 2002, the library was situated along the [[Seine]], on two floors of an annex to the Cité Internationale des Arts, and then moved to the CNR conservatory, rue de Madrid. Since 2006 the library is part of the Mediathèque Hector Berlioz at the [[Conservatoire de Paris]]. It was renamed ''Library Božidar Kantušer'' in honor of the composer [[Božidar Kantušer]], one of its founding members and its director from 1968 to 1999. The other founding members of the association are [[Léon Barzin]], [[Louis-Noël Belaubre]], Jacques Phytilis, [[Jean-Jacques Werner]], [[Pierre Wissmer]], Didier Duclos.

==K== *'''K''' – Is used as an abbreviation for [[1000 (number)#In mathematics|1,000]]. For example, $225K would be understood to mean $225,000, and $3.6K would be understood to mean $3,600. Multiple K's are not commonly used to represent larger numbers. In other words, it would look odd to use $1.2KK to represent $1,200,000. *'''KIBOR''' - Karachi Interbank Offered Rate *'''KPI''' – "Key Performance Indicators" refers to a type of performance measurement. An organization may use KPIs to evaluate its success, or to evaluate the success of a particular activity in which it is engaged. *'''KYC''' – "Know Your Customer" refers to due diligence activities that financial institutions and other regulated companies must perform to ascertain relevant information.

==R== *'''RBI''' – [[Reserve Bank of India]] *'''RBA''' – [[Reserve Bank of Australia]] *'''RE''' – [[Retained Earnings]] *'''RFI''' – [[Request for information]] *'''RFP''' – [[Request for Proposal]] *'''RFQ''' – [[Request for Quotation]] *'''RFX''' – Generic name for a Request for Information, Proposal or Quotation *'''ROA''' – [[Return on assets]] *'''ROCE''' – [[Return On Capital Employed]] *'''ROE''' – [[Return on Equity]] *'''ROI''' – [[Return on Investment]] *'''ROIC''' – [[Return on Invested Capital]] *'''RONA''' – [[Return on net assets]] *'''ROS''' – [[Return on Sales]] *'''RR''' – [[Resource rent]] *'''RSP''' – [[Retail selling price]] *'''R&D''' – [[Research and Development]] *'''RC''' – [[Retail Company]]
==S== *'''S<sub>t</sub>''' – [[Sales#Accounting|Sales]], during time period ''t''. *'''S&M''' - Sales & Marketing *'''S&OP''' - [[Sales and operations planning]] *'''SAAS''' – [[Software as a service|Software-as-a-Service]] *'''SCM''' – [[Supply Chain Management]] *'''SCBA''' – [[Social Cost Benefit Analysis]] *'''SEBI''' – [[Securities and Exchange Board of India]] *'''SEC''' - [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] *'''SG&A''' – [[SG&A|Sales, General, and Administrative expenses]] *'''SIR''' – [[Stores Issuance Requisition]] *'''SIOP''' – [[Sales Inventory and Operations Plan]] *'''SIV''' – [[Structured investment vehicle]] *'''SKU''' – [[Stock keeping unit]] *'''SME''' - [[Small and Medium Enterprises]] *'''SOHO''' – [[Small Office/Home Office]] *'''SOX''' – [[Sarbanes-Oxley]] *'''SROI''' - [[Social return on investment]] *'''SOP''' - [[Standard Operating Procedure]] *'''SOW''' - [[Statement Of Work]] *'''SLA'''* -[[Service Level Agreement]] *'''SUA''' - [[Start Up Agreement]]
==T== *'''TCO''' – [[Total Cost of Ownership]] *'''TCV''' – [[Total Contract Value]] *'''TSR''' – [[Total Shareholder Return]] *'''TB''' – [[Transaction Banking]] *'''TBD''' – [[To Be Defined]] *'''TBC''' - [[To Be Completed]] *'''TQM'''- [[Total Quality Management]] *'''TOTW'''- [[Time Off for Time Worked]] *'''TTM'''- Trailing Twelve Months

{{other uses|Marshall Field (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person | name = Marshall Field | image = Marshall Field circa 1915 (cropped).jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1834|8|18|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Conway, Massachusetts|Conway]], [[Franklin County, Massachusetts|Franklin County]], [[Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1906|1|16|1834|8|18|mf=y}} | death_place = [[New York City]], [[New York County]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | occupation = Founder of [[Marshall Field's|Marshall Field and Company]] | spouse = Nannie Douglas Scott, Delia Spencer | parents = John Field IV and Fidelia Nash | children = Louis Field, Marshall Field Jr., [[Ethel Beatty|Ethel Field]]}}
'''Marshall Field''' (August 18, 1834{{spaced ndash}}January 16, 1906) was an American [[entrepreneur]] and the founder of [[Marshall Field's|Marshall Field and Company]], the [[Chicago]]-based [[department stores]]. His business was renowned for its then-exceptional level of quality and customer service. Field is also known for some of his philanthropic donations, providing funding for the [[Field Museum of Natural History]] and donating land for the campus of the [[University of Chicago]].
==Early life== Marshall Field was born on a [[farm]] in [[Conway, Massachusetts|Conway]], [[Franklin County, Massachusetts|Franklin County]], [[Massachusetts]],<ref name=Mises>[[Orison Swett Marden|Marden, Orison Swett]]. [https://mises.org/daily/5013/How-Marshall-Field-Succeeded How Marshall Field Succeeded], ''[[Mises Institute]]''</ref> the son of John Field IV and wife Fidelia Nash. His family was descended from [[Puritans]] who had come to America as early as 1650.
At the age of 17, he moved to [[Pittsfield, Massachusetts|Pittsfield]], [[Berkshire County, Massachusetts|Berkshire County]], [[Massachusetts]], where he first worked in a [[dry goods]] store.<ref name="nrhpinv2">{{Cite journal|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory-Nomination: Marshall Field & Company Store|url={{NHLS url|id=78001123}} |format=pdf|date=March 1977 |author=Ralph J. Christian |publisher=National Park Service}} and {{NHLS url|id=78001123|title=''Accompanying six photos, exterior and interior, from 1960 and undated''|photos=y}} {{small|(32 KB)}} (A biography of Marshall Field is included)</ref> He left [[Massachusetts]] at the age of 18 for new opportunities in the rapidly expanding West. In 1856, at age 21, he went to live with his brother in [[Chicago, Illinois]], and obtained employment at leading dry goods merchant [[Cooley, Wadsworth & Co.]], which was to become Cooley, Farwell & Co. in 1857.
==Career== Field quickly rose through the ranks of Cooley, Farwell & Co. In 1862 for financial reasons Cooley left the firm. That same year Field purchased a partnership and the firm reorganized as Farwell, Field & Co.<ref>Robert L. Gale, “The Gay Nineties in America: A Cultural Dictionary of the 1890s,” Westport, Conn.: Greenwood, 1992, 123.</ref> [[John V. Farwell]] appreciated Field’s keen business acumen; however, when it came to personality, the two were very different. Field’s stuffy efficiency rode on Farwell’s more relaxed and cheery demeanor.<ref>Twyman, “History of Marshall Field & Co.,” Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania, 1954, 13.</ref> At a time when business collaboration entailed extensive personal interaction, this partnership wouldn’t last long.
In January 1865, Field and a partner, [[Levi Leiter]], accepted an offer to become senior partners at the dry goods establishment of [[Potter Palmer]]. The new firm became known as "Field, Palmer, Leiter & Co." In 1867, after Field and Leiter could afford to buy him out, Palmer withdrew from the firm, and it was renamed "Field, Leiter & Company." In 1867 Field, Leiter & Company reported revenues of $12 million.<ref>Schlup, Leonard. "Historical Dictionary of the Gilded Age." (Armonk, NY: M.E. Sharpe, 2003), p. 160</ref> Like many Chicago businessman, Field's company was badly affected by the [[Great Chicago Fire]] of 1871, but reopened relatively quickly. The company also survived the [[Panic of 1873]] because of their relatively low levels of debt. By 1881 Field had forced Leiter to sell his share of the business, and changed the store's name to "Marshall Field and Company".
Field took an early 19th-century consumer landscape that was centered around the principle of [[caveat emptor]], or "buyer beware", and transformed it into a plush shopping experience fit for the Gilded Age. Unconditional refunds, consistent pricing and international imports are among the Field innovations that became standards in quality retailing. Field's employees were also instructed not to push products on uninterested customers as was common practice in stores of the period. The quotes "Give the lady what she wants" and "[[The customer is always right]]" are attributed to Field.{{efn|The latter may have been invented by [[Harry Gordon Selfridge]] while we was working for Field.<ref>[http://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/106700.html The customer is always right<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The original saying was, "Assume that the customer is right until it is plain beyond all question he is not."<ref>Schlup and Ryan, “Historical Dictionary,” M.E. Sharpe, 2003, 161.</ref>}}
Though most famous today for his retail business, during his lifetime his wholesale business made far more money. During the 1880s, Field's wholesale business generated 5 times more revenue than retail annually.<ref>O'Gorman, James F. "The Marshall Field Wholesale Store: Materials Towards a Monograph." ''Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians'', Vol 37, No 3, October 1978. pp 175-194. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/989208 JSTOR]</ref> The wholesale business even had its own landmark building, the [[Marshall Field's Wholesale Store]], erected in 1887. Revenue from the Marshall Field's retail business did not surpass the company's wholesale business until after Field's death.
Field was highly suspicious of [[trade union|organized labor]] throughout his career, and prohibited unionization among his employees. During the time of the [[Haymarket Riot]], the wives of the defendants initiated an appeal, to which all of the local businessmen agreed except for Field. Journalist and reformer [[Henry Demarest Lloyd]] led a national campaign to grant clemency. Even bankers like [[Lyman J. Gage]] favored clemency, believing that moderation would lead to improved relations between capital and labor. Potter Palmer and Charles Hutchinson were inclined to agree, but Marshall Field was not. A number of other men confided to Gage that they were not willing to publicly disagree with Field, the wealthiest and most powerful businessman in Chicago.<ref>{{cite web |year=2003|title=People & Events: Marshall Field (1834-1906) and Midwestern Commerce |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/chicago/peopleevents/p_field.html |work=Chicago: City of the Century |publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] Online |accessdate=2008-05-27}}</ref> Field would also oppose organized labor during the Teamster's Strike in 1905. {{notelist}}
==Personal life== Field avoided political and social intrigue, instead focusing on his work and on supporting his family and his favorite philanthropies. Field was a very active member of The [[Commercial Club of Chicago]] and the [[Jekyll Island Club]] aka The Millionaires Club on [[Jekyll Island, Georgia]].
Field married twice. In 1863, he married Nannie Douglas Scott of [[Ironton, Ohio]].<ref>[http://www.lawrencecountyohio.com/families/q_z/Scott1.htm Lawrence County, Ohio Historical Society]</ref> They had two sons and a daughter, but one son, Louis, died in 1866 as an infant. The surviving children were Marshall Field Jr. and [[Ethel Beatty|Ethel Field]]. Their son, Marshall Jr. (1868–1905), married Albertine Huck, and they were the parents of Gwendolyn Mary Field, who married [[Edmonstone baronets|Sir Archibald Charles Edmonstone, 6th Baronet]]. Field's Ethel was married twice: first to Arthur Magie Tree, to whom she bore one son, [[Ronald Tree]], and then in 1901 to [[David Beatty, 1st Earl Beatty]], to whom she bore two sons, [[David Beatty, 2nd Earl Beatty]] and [[Peter Beatty|Peter]].
After the death of his first wife Nannie in 1896, Field married longtime friend Delia Spencer, widow Caton. They had no children together.
==Death == Field died in [[New York City, New York]], on January 16, 1906 at age 71 from a case of [[pneumonia]] contracted after playing [[golf]] on [[New Year's Day]] with his nephew, his secretary and [[Abraham Lincoln]]’s oldest son [[Robert Todd Lincoln|Robert Todd]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Fortune Builders: Chicago's Famous Families|author=Edwin Darby|publisher=Garrett County Press|date=November 6, 2011}}</ref> Field was buried on January 19. He was interred in the [[Graceland Cemetery]] in Chicago.
==Legacy== After his death, Field's estate was to be held in trust for 40 years for his two grandsons, Henry Field and [[Marshall Field III]]. In 1905, Field's fortune was valued at $125 million.<ref>Leonard Schlup and James Ryan, “Historical Dictionary of the Gilded Age,” M.E. Sharpe, 2003, 160.</ref> Henry Field died in 1917 and was thus unable to collect his inheritance, leaving the Field fortune in the hands of Marshall Field III.<ref>{{cite news|title=Henry Field Dies in Hospital Here|publisher=The New York Times|date=July 9, 1917|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/07/09/96253971.pdf}}</ref>
The [[Field Museum of Natural History]] was named after him in 1894 after he gave it an endowment of one million dollars.<ref>Alexander (1996), p. 55</ref> Field was initially reluctant to do so, reportedly saying "I don't know anything about a museum and I don't care to know anything about a museum. I'm not going to give you a million dollars."<ref>Quoted in Alexander (1996), p. 55.</ref> However he later relented after railroad supplies magnate [[Edward E. Ayer]], another early benefactor (and later first president) of the museum, convinced Field that his everlasting legacy would be achieved by financing the project.<ref>See Alexander (1996), pp. 55–56. Ayer reportedly convinced Field with the words, "You can sell dry goods until hell freezes over, but in 25 years, you will be absolutely forgotten." See Anderson (1921).</ref> The year after his death the Field Museum received a further $8,000,000 in accordance with his [[Will (law)|will]].<ref>Alexander (1996), p. 56</ref>
The [[University of Chicago]] was founded by both Field and New York's [[John D. Rockefeller]], to rival nearby [[Evanston, Illinois|Evanston]]'s [[Northwestern University]].<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/menofaffairsgall00chic#page/1/mode/1up Men of Affairs: a gallery of cartoon portraits], Chicago Evening Post, 1906; page 1.</ref>
A bust of Marshall Field stands aside other early 20th century Chicago industry magnates on the north riverbank on the [[Chicago River]] facing the [[Merchandise Mart]].
==See also== *[[Marshall Field's]], the eponymous department store he founded. *[[Field Enterprises]], holding company for newspapers and TV stations. *[[Marshall Field III]] (1893–1956), publisher, ''[[Chicago Sun]]'' founder, [[investment banker]], bankrolled [[Saul Alinsky]] *[[Marshall Field IV]], publisher, owner of the ''[[Chicago Sun]]'' newspaper *[[Ted Field|Frederick "Ted" Field]] (founder of [[Interscope Communications]] and co-founder of [[Interscope Records]])

Lamb}} * {{cite book |author=Alexander, Edward P. |authorlink=Edward P. Alderson |location=Walnut Creek, CA |publisher=[[AltaMira Press]], in cooperation with the American Association for State and Local History |isbn=0-7619-9155-7 |oclc=33983419}} * {{cite web |author=Anderson, Jon |date=1921-05-02 |title=The Field Museum |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/chi-chicagodays-fieldmuseum-story,0,7118746.story |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |publisher=Tribune Company |accessdate=2008-05-27}} * {{cite book |author=Green, James |year=2007 |title=Death in the Haymarket |location=New York |publisher=Anchor Books}} * {{cite book |author=Madson, Axel |year=2002 |chapter= |title= The Marshall Fields |editor= |location= New York |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]}} * {{cite web |author=Rhoads, Mark |date=2006-08-22 |title=Illinois Hall of Fame - Marshal Field |url=http://illinoisreview.typepad.com/illinoisreview/2006/08/illinois_hall_o_15.html |work=Illinois Review |accessdate=2008-05-27}} * {{cite book |author=Sullivan, Timothy E. |year=1999 |chapter=Marshall Field |title=American National Biography |editor=James Garraty (ed.) |location=Oxford |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]}} * {{cite book |author=Tebbel, John |year=1947 |chapter= |title= The Marshall Fields |editor= |location=New York |publisher=[[E. P. Dutton]]}} * Wendt, Lloyd and Herman Kogan, (1952) ''Give the Lady What She Wants! The Story of Marshall Field & Company''. New York: [[Rand McNally and Company]]
